VOL. XXXII, No. 21

DR. WIGHT SPEAKS
ON COLLEGE LIFE
Entertains Friendship Council
With Interesting Address
FAVORS STUDENT CONTROL
Tells Amusing Anecdotes of Life
At Scotch Universities
Amusing anecdotes and reminiscenses formed the basis of Dr.
Carol Van Buren Wi'ght's address
at the Y. M. C. A. Friendship Council supper last Tuesday evening.
Most of these -very interesting
stories had morals which were exPlanatory of what Dr. Wight
termed "the Phenomena -of. student
life." When college students get
out of hand the blame usually rests
Upon the faculty, said Dr. Wight.
The recent Harvard-Yale fracas
was caused in part by the attempt
of the faculty to interfere with matters not strictly in their own province.
The college takes a grave responsibility in the matter of lending
official support to extra-curricular
activities, inasmuch as they are held
responsible for any damage incurred, which in its turn decreases
the salaries of the unfortunate collegiate professors.

ic

RE

Professors too Critical

College professors are too prone
to criticize students for doing things
they themselves did in ,the past.
Dr. Wight then called upon his
memory for a few facts to prove
that students are not as wild as
formerly. Nowadays, students do
not get up a drinking party, go on
a boat trip down the bay, and after
taking command of the boat, proceed to demolish it.
Methods of raising money in
Scotland for the support of universities were described very amusingly by Dr. Wight. Some time
back the students raised money by
raising Cain. In a body the students would descend upon the police court, interrupting all business
until a certain amount had been
Paid by the judge. Much money
could be collected by variations of
this method. By dressing up as
doctors and getting a wagon load
of the entrails of cattle from the
local stockyards and strewing these
around the streets, the better residential sections would be forced to
Pay the levy in order to be safe
from the "baptism." The feminine
members of the student body used
to collect money from the clergy
under the threat of being kissed!
While at the present time this
Inethod would be apt to fall
through, in those days it was very
effective.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 16, 1927

WARFIELD RESIGNS
AS DRAMATIC HEAD
H. Ridgely Warfield, president of the Barnstormers
Club, has been forced by pressure of studies to resign his
post. Warfield's resignation
was announced to the Barnstormers last Wednesday.
Action on Warfield's announcement will be taken at
the Barnstormer meeting to be
held next Tuesday; at that
time a new president will be
elected. In resigning., Warfield follows in the steps of
I. Evans Rodgers.
In the absence of Walter B.
Swindell, Barnstormer coach,
rehearsals have been. postponed until after the Christmas recess.

FOUR-LEGGED BROTHERS PACE, HOWEVER

At last the much disputed point
as to whether crawling babies pace
or trot has been decided in favor
of the latter. This most cogent argument, which has been thrashed
out at nearly every important psychological meeting during the last
quarter of a century, has at last been
conclusively settled in a manner
satisfaatory to both parties with
the co-operation of a camera, a cat,
bulldog, and a group of babies at

Council.

Results of the experiment, just

reported by Dr. Lenoir H. Burnside, show that babies, being much
more naive or perhaps sophisticated,
are much more individual in their
ways of getting around than their
staid elders are. Generally speaking, a human being's first attempts
at locomotion are merely struggling
forward with much floundering of
arms and legs. Later the baby's
arms begin to work, left, right, in
alternating rhythm, while legs are
still dragged or hitched after him
in a most unrhythmic fashion. Then
he begins to carry his abdomen
clear of the floor, and, at last, he
develops a left-right motion of his
legs, alternating them with his arms.
The dog and the cat, not being
so intellectual, moved along the
floor in a pacing gait, the weight
of the body being borne very cleverly without spilling, by the two
legs on one side, then by the two
legs on the other, much like an inebriate.
But all' of the babies trotted,
keeping their weight balanced diagonally between a leg one one side
and an arm on the other, though
some of the younger feminine
crawlers were single-.footed.

Musical Club Gives
Concert at Be! Air
Members to Attend Dinner and Play
at State Armory Tomorrow

Tomorrow night the Musical
Club will hold its third concert of
the season in the State Armory at
Be! Air, Md. Preceding the concert, the members of the club will
be the guests of Mr. and Mrs.
G. Alexis Shriver at a supper to
be held at "Olvaney," the Shriver
estate.
This concert is being held under
the auspices of the Be! Air Athletic
Association. "The Musical 'Clubs
have performed at Be! Air on several previous occasions and have
always been accorded a warm reception," said Manager Charles McElfresh. "This concert will very
likely become an annual fixture on
the club's schedule."
The concert, which is scheduled
for 8.30 P. M., will be followed by
a dance at 10.30. The program is
to be the same as that of the Walbrook and Guilford concerts.

Strader Easy Choice

The election of captain was the
last event on the program and it
did not take long for the players to
decide that "Dal" Strader would
be the best man to lead the team
which will, as Dr. Van Orman said,
"have to uphold the reputation set
up by this year's eleven." Paul
Frisch will manage the team.
Immediately after the banquet
was over the hall was cleared and
a dance was held for the members
of the squad and their friends.

minutes late, and leave the classroom with an exhuberant feeling
that it has, somehow or other, "put something over" on somebody.
Not so with the members of Psychology I, although it must be
said that their case is somewhat different.

IF YOU GOT AN INFORMAL OR TWO
If there really is no Santa Claus, there will be many to find it
out this week when the informals are announced to their recipients. How many frosh, we wonder, will be disillusioned when,
thinking they had done very fine work in a course, they receive
a black 6 or 5.5! But don't worry, you receivers of informals,
for remember the story that is told of the Phi Bete who netted
six sixes in December, and turned them all upside down in February. No, all is not lost!

Instead of actually missing their lectures, they are given the
opportunity of seeing how psychological tests are conducted, from
the point of view of the conductee. They are used as reactors;
but, they •say, they do not receive their forty cents per hour!
Why, they say, should they be deprived of their inalienable right
to hear the instructor expatiate upon—well, to tell the truth, upon
something which may be asked in the examination?
We have been importuned by a number of the students in
"Psych" I to protest against their use as reactors when the department can secure such reactors any afternoon at the rate of forty
cents each. To the contrary, we think that they are extremely lacking in gratitude. After all, they should be glad, not only of the
introduction of an occasional variation in the daily run of lectures,
but should consider the opportunity to find out just how modern
psychologists carry on their experimentations—an opportunity
worth having.
Some students, though, can never be satisfied. If the lectures
in a course are dull, they find fault with the poor instructor; if
an instructor makes an attempt to break the montony of regular
lectures by introducing something novel occasionally, he is accused
of attempting to thwart the students' bloodthirsty chase after
knowledge!
We wonder how these same students would act if the instructor
were ill for a week. Would they demand a capable substitute?
You know the answer as well as we do.

UNHONORED HEROES?
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
The freshman football team will
receive their class numerals at the
Class' expense; but, in all probability, the freshman lacrosse team will
not. This seems a bit unfair.
Both teams undoubtedly did their
best in their respective games, but
the lacrosse team was the one that
actually helped remove the regulations by winning the second interclass contest. So I fail to see
how the class can conscientiously
buy the football team numerals
Without doing as much for the lacrosse team.
T. P.

ON RECENT WESTINGHOUSE JOBS

The Homestead Steel Mills
Where do young college men get in a
large industrial organization? Have
they opportunity to exercise creative
talent? Is individual work recognized?

on the hill-top near
Homestead,Pennsylvania, and
look out over the Carnegie Steel
Company's vast works. Your eye
falls on a huge new building,
covering 30 acres. It is the
structural steel department, and
here electricity performs every
mechanical operation in steel
rolling from the
soaking pits on
through to the
shipping departTAND

ment. This Homestead electrification, predominantly Westinghouse, is one of the most notable
in history —notable because of the
number and size of the motors
employed and notable because of
new features of automatic control
introduced for the first time.
This is a type of engineering
that only an organization of the
size and resources of Westinghouse
can undertake. Achieving the
stupendous, the never-before-

undertaken, is not rare here.
Hence young men of capacity, of
enterprise, of genius, are offered
much to challenge their imaginations and abilities.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 16, 1927

HOPKINS MUSICAL
ASSOCIATION MEETS
Philip S. Morgan is Elected
New President
Holding a meeting recently, the
Johns Hopkins Musical Association elected Philip S. Morgan its
president. The other officers elected were: Frederick H. Gottleib,
vice-president, Ferdinand C. Smith,
executive secretary, and Charles H.
Cole, librarian.
The Board of the Johns Hopkins
University has ratified the election
of these trustees: Dr. Frank J.
Goodnow, president; Dr. Joseph S.
Ames, Dean of the College of Arts
and Sciences; and Dr. John B.
Whitehead, Dean of the Engineering School. The election of these
doctors was also ratified: John H.
Latane, David M. Robinson, Frank
Morley, Thomas S. Cullen, Thomas
R. Browne, Hugh H. Young, and R.
L. Dohme.
The following were elected:
Messrs. Frank B. Cohn, Jonas Hamburger, Frederick W. Wood, P. S.
Morgan, F. H. Gottleib, and F. C.
Smith.
Mr. Morgan, who is an alumnus
of the University, has been a member of the Orchestra since its organization. He was a very close
friend of the late Edwin L. Turnbull, who was the founder of the
Musical Association and the Orchestra. He founded this organiza-

MILITARY ORDER
HOLDS INITIATION
Ferninand C. Schmiedicke,
captain of Company D of the
R. 0. T. C. unit at Hopkins,
was initiated into Scabbard
and Blade, honorary military
society, last Monday after
drill. Schmiedicke was to
have been initiated at the regular meeting last month, but
was prevented from doing so
by football practice. The
Scabbard and Blade will hold
its next meeting and banquet
some time during January.
Pins will be presented to the
new members of the military
fraternity at a review to be
held after the Christmas recess.

tion in 1919.
The orchestra is not necessarily
all Hopkins talent, as the present
organization is composed of musicians from both the University and
the outside. Only amateur musicians are eligible, however.
The first concert of the organization was given under the leadership
of Bart Wirtz, who is teaching at
the Peabody Conservatory of Music and at the Samuel Ready School.
The Musical Association will
later appear at several large concerts. These concerts will be given
respectively at the Maryland Casualty and at the new Baltimore Museum of Art.

Pick Adams Debate
• Teams in January
Adams Debate tryouts have been
postponed until after the Christmas
recess, according to an announcement by Norman B. Gardiner, president of the Debating Council.
Within a week after January 3,
junior and senior teams will be
picked to debate on the question:
-Resolved, that the United States
shall not forcibly intervene in Latin
America except in time of war
(with this country)." Candidates
for the team will have an opportunity to delve into the subject over
the holidays.
So far, plans for the intercollegiate debates of March and April
are very nebulous. It is hoped that
the old Triangular Debate with
Washington and Lee and North
Carolina will be held this year.
Two or three trips are also being
planned.
By the middle of January plans
for the spring should be nearing
completion. Many communications
have already been received from
universities desiring debates. The
Adams Debate will be held on February 9, before the spring forensic
season begins.

VOL. XXXII, No. 21

DR. WIGHT SPEAKS
ON COLLEGE LIFE
Entertains Friendship Council
With Interesting Address
FAVORS STUDENT CONTROL
Tells Amusing Anecdotes of Life
At Scotch Universities
Amusing anecdotes and reminiscenses formed the basis of Dr.
Carol Van Buren Wi'ght's address
at the Y. M. C. A. Friendship Council supper last Tuesday evening.
Most of these -very interesting
stories had morals which were exPlanatory of what Dr. Wight
termed "the Phenomena -of. student
life." When college students get
out of hand the blame usually rests
Upon the faculty, said Dr. Wight.
The recent Harvard-Yale fracas
was caused in part by the attempt
of the faculty to interfere with matters not strictly in their own province.
The college takes a grave responsibility in the matter of lending
official support to extra-curricular
activities, inasmuch as they are held
responsible for any damage incurred, which in its turn decreases
the salaries of the unfortunate collegiate professors.

ic

RE

Professors too Critical

College professors are too prone
to criticize students for doing things
they themselves did in ,the past.
Dr. Wight then called upon his
memory for a few facts to prove
that students are not as wild as
formerly. Nowadays, students do
not get up a drinking party, go on
a boat trip down the bay, and after
taking command of the boat, proceed to demolish it.
Methods of raising money in
Scotland for the support of universities were described very amusingly by Dr. Wight. Some time
back the students raised money by
raising Cain. In a body the students would descend upon the police court, interrupting all business
until a certain amount had been
Paid by the judge. Much money
could be collected by variations of
this method. By dressing up as
doctors and getting a wagon load
of the entrails of cattle from the
local stockyards and strewing these
around the streets, the better residential sections would be forced to
Pay the levy in order to be safe
from the "baptism." The feminine
members of the student body used
to collect money from the clergy
under the threat of being kissed!
While at the present time this
Inethod would be apt to fall
through, in those days it was very
effective.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 16, 1927

WARFIELD RESIGNS
AS DRAMATIC HEAD
H. Ridgely Warfield, president of the Barnstormers
Club, has been forced by pressure of studies to resign his
post. Warfield's resignation
was announced to the Barnstormers last Wednesday.
Action on Warfield's announcement will be taken at
the Barnstormer meeting to be
held next Tuesday; at that
time a new president will be
elected. In resigning., Warfield follows in the steps of
I. Evans Rodgers.
In the absence of Walter B.
Swindell, Barnstormer coach,
rehearsals have been. postponed until after the Christmas recess.

FOUR-LEGGED BROTHERS PACE, HOWEVER

At last the much disputed point
as to whether crawling babies pace
or trot has been decided in favor
of the latter. This most cogent argument, which has been thrashed
out at nearly every important psychological meeting during the last
quarter of a century, has at last been
conclusively settled in a manner
satisfaatory to both parties with
the co-operation of a camera, a cat,
bulldog, and a group of babies at

College men and non-college men floor in a given position. In front

hence the value of the Friendship by a string, and as the baby set out
Council.

Recitation of a few lines of out its pictures.
turns' poems concluded the talk.
Results of the experiment, just

reported by Dr. Lenoir H. Burnside, show that babies, being much
more naive or perhaps sophisticated,
are much more individual in their
ways of getting around than their
staid elders are. Generally speaking, a human being's first attempts
at locomotion are merely struggling
forward with much floundering of
arms and legs. Later the baby's
arms begin to work, left, right, in
alternating rhythm, while legs are
still dragged or hitched after him
in a most unrhythmic fashion. Then
he begins to carry his abdomen
clear of the floor, and, at last, he
develops a left-right motion of his
legs, alternating them with his arms.
The dog and the cat, not being
so intellectual, moved along the
floor in a pacing gait, the weight
of the body being borne very cleverly without spilling, by the two
legs on one side, then by the two
legs on the other, much like an inebriate.
But all' of the babies trotted,
keeping their weight balanced diagonally between a leg one one side
and an arm on the other, though
some of the younger feminine
crawlers were single-.footed.

Musical Club Gives
Concert at Be! Air
Members to Attend Dinner and Play
at State Armory Tomorrow

Tomorrow night the Musical
Club will hold its third concert of
the season in the State Armory at
Be! Air, Md. Preceding the concert, the members of the club will
be the guests of Mr. and Mrs.
G. Alexis Shriver at a supper to
be held at "Olvaney," the Shriver
estate.
This concert is being held under
the auspices of the Be! Air Athletic
Association. "The Musical 'Clubs
have performed at Be! Air on several previous occasions and have
always been accorded a warm reception," said Manager Charles McElfresh. "This concert will very
likely become an annual fixture on
the club's schedule."
The concert, which is scheduled
for 8.30 P. M., will be followed by
a dance at 10.30. The program is
to be the same as that of the Walbrook and Guilford concerts.

Strader Easy Choice

The election of captain was the
last event on the program and it
did not take long for the players to
decide that "Dal" Strader would
be the best man to lead the team
which will, as Dr. Van Orman said,
"have to uphold the reputation set
up by this year's eleven." Paul
Frisch will manage the team.
Immediately after the banquet
was over the hall was cleared and
a dance was held for the members
of the squad and their friends.

IF YOU GOT AN INFORMAL OR TWO
If there really is no Santa Claus, there will be many to find it
out this week when the informals are announced to their recipients. How many frosh, we wonder, will be disillusioned when,
thinking they had done very fine work in a course, they receive
a black 6 or 5.5! But don't worry, you receivers of informals,
for remember the story that is told of the Phi Bete who netted
six sixes in December, and turned them all upside down in February. No, all is not lost!

Instead of actually missing their lectures, they are given the
opportunity of seeing how psychological tests are conducted, from
the point of view of the conductee. They are used as reactors;
but, they •say, they do not receive their forty cents per hour!
Why, they say, should they be deprived of their inalienable right
to hear the instructor expatiate upon—well, to tell the truth, upon
something which may be asked in the examination?
We have been importuned by a number of the students in
"Psych" I to protest against their use as reactors when the department can secure such reactors any afternoon at the rate of forty
cents each. To the contrary, we think that they are extremely lacking in gratitude. After all, they should be glad, not only of the
introduction of an occasional variation in the daily run of lectures,
but should consider the opportunity to find out just how modern
psychologists carry on their experimentations—an opportunity
worth having.
Some students, though, can never be satisfied. If the lectures
in a course are dull, they find fault with the poor instructor; if
an instructor makes an attempt to break the montony of regular
lectures by introducing something novel occasionally, he is accused
of attempting to thwart the students' bloodthirsty chase after
knowledge!
We wonder how these same students would act if the instructor
were ill for a week. Would they demand a capable substitute?
You know the answer as well as we do.

UNHONORED HEROES?
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
The freshman football team will
receive their class numerals at the
Class' expense; but, in all probability, the freshman lacrosse team will
not. This seems a bit unfair.
Both teams undoubtedly did their
best in their respective games, but
the lacrosse team was the one that
actually helped remove the regulations by winning the second interclass contest. So I fail to see
how the class can conscientiously
buy the football team numerals
Without doing as much for the lacrosse team.
T. P.

large industrial organization? Have
they opportunity to exercise creative
talent? Is individual work recognized?

on the hill-top near

Company's vast works. Your eye
falls on a huge new building,
covering 30 acres. It is the
structural steel department, and
here electricity performs every
mechanical operation in steel
rolling from the

through to the

ment. This Homestead electrification, predominantly Westinghouse, is one of the most notable
in history —notable because of the

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 16, 1927

HOPKINS MUSICAL
ASSOCIATION MEETS
Philip S. Morgan is Elected
New President
Holding a meeting recently, the
Johns Hopkins Musical Association elected Philip S. Morgan its
president. The other officers elected were: Frederick H. Gottleib,
vice-president, Ferdinand C. Smith,
executive secretary, and Charles H.
Cole, librarian.
The Board of the Johns Hopkins
University has ratified the election
of these trustees: Dr. Frank J.
Goodnow, president; Dr. Joseph S.
Ames, Dean of the College of Arts
and Sciences; and Dr. John B.
Whitehead, Dean of the Engineering School. The election of these
doctors was also ratified: John H.
Latane, David M. Robinson, Frank
Morley, Thomas S. Cullen, Thomas
R. Browne, Hugh H. Young, and R.
L. Dohme.
The following were elected:
Messrs. Frank B. Cohn, Jonas Hamburger, Frederick W. Wood, P. S.
Morgan, F. H. Gottleib, and F. C.
Smith.
Mr. Morgan, who is an alumnus
of the University, has been a member of the Orchestra since its organization. He was a very close
friend of the late Edwin L. Turnbull, who was the founder of the
Musical Association and the Orchestra. He founded this organiza-

MILITARY ORDER
HOLDS INITIATION
Ferninand C. Schmiedicke,
captain of Company D of the
R. 0. T. C. unit at Hopkins,
was initiated into Scabbard
and Blade, honorary military
society, last Monday after
drill. Schmiedicke was to
have been initiated at the regular meeting last month, but
was prevented from doing so
by football practice. The
Scabbard and Blade will hold
its next meeting and banquet
some time during January.
Pins will be presented to the
new members of the military
fraternity at a review to be
held after the Christmas recess.

tion in 1919.
The orchestra is not necessarily
all Hopkins talent, as the present
organization is composed of musicians from both the University and
the outside. Only amateur musicians are eligible, however.
The first concert of the organization was given under the leadership
of Bart Wirtz, who is teaching at
the Peabody Conservatory of Music and at the Samuel Ready School.
The Musical Association will
later appear at several large concerts. These concerts will be given
respectively at the Maryland Casualty and at the new Baltimore Museum of Art.

Pick Adams Debate
• Teams in January
Adams Debate tryouts have been
postponed until after the Christmas
recess, according to an announcement by Norman B. Gardiner, president of the Debating Council.
Within a week after January 3,
junior and senior teams will be
picked to debate on the question:
-Resolved, that the United States
shall not forcibly intervene in Latin
America except in time of war
(with this country)." Candidates
for the team will have an opportunity to delve into the subject over
the holidays.
So far, plans for the intercollegiate debates of March and April
are very nebulous. It is hoped that
the old Triangular Debate with
Washington and Lee and North
Carolina will be held this year.
Two or three trips are also being
planned.
By the middle of January plans
for the spring should be nearing
completion. Many communications
have already been received from
universities desiring debates. The
Adams Debate will be held on February 9, before the spring forensic
season begins.
